text: Does anyone know if you can use `blog_recent_topic_posts` to specify several topics? Looks like it only accepts one. But I’d want to look for posts with topics X, Y or Z.
Otherwise, I’m guessing I’d use `blog_recent_posts` and look in that feed for anything with those topics specified.
Depending on what you’re doing you could add the topic slugs as classes then hide/show posts with CSS
We’ve done that to sort resource centers, events etc
Id prefer not to use CSS to hide things as that just loads the DOM up with un-needed HTML. I’d rather just look in the loop and exclude/include right there.

<@U7AU6414J> this may help, it's for related topics. But you may be able to use it. - <https://designers.HubSpot.com/tutorials/creating-a-related-post-section-with-hubl#multiple-related-topics-listing>
You could run the loop with if statements for each topic then kill it after it succeeds a certain amount of times?
or just run `{% set topic_posts = blog_recent_topic_posts('default', 'X') %}` for each topic and combine them into one array and loop through that.
You would have to run some sort of filter on the combined array after so that they would all be displayed chronologically
o interesting, ill try this out, thanks!
can custom modules import macros? what is the best practice for that with custom modules?
you couldn’t before but with the alpha that was announced by shawn bristow that might now be possible
Is there a method of pulling in a menu so that it can be looped over?
